conclusion: The fibre core is homogeneous glass (refractive index n) surrounded by air (n_air=1).
Its circular cross-section has diameter D. When the fibre is bent its centre-line ('axis') becomes an arc of a circle of radius r (the bend-radius we have to keep large enough).
Because the fibre is bent, every meridional ray that propagates parallel to the axis is no longer everywhere parallel to the local outer surface.

When such a ray meets the outer wall the angle it makes with the outward normal is slightly smaller than the axial angle it had in the straight fibre; the reduction equals the small geometric angle δ=arcsin(D/2r) ≈ D/2r, which is the angle subtended by the core radius at the bend centre.
Before bending, the largest axial angle a ray can have and still remain totally internally reflected is the critical angle θ_c=arcsin(1/n).

premise: After bending, that same ray meets the outer wall with an incidence angle reduced by δ; to avoid radiating out we must still have θ_inc=θ_c−δ ≥ θ_c(crit), i.e. it must not fall below the original critical angle.
conclusion: The limiting (loss-free) case is therefore θ_c−δ=θ_c(crit)⟹δ=0.

premise: Any non-zero reduction must still leave the incidence angle at least θ_c(crit); hence we require δ ≤ θ_c ⟹ D/2r ≤ arcsin(1/n).
conclusion: For the modest bends used in practice arcsin(1/n) is a small angle so we can drop the 'arc sin' and write θ_c≈1/n. The inequality then becomes D/2r ≤ 1/n.
The turning radius of the fibre’s centre-line must be at least nD/2.
